results.title: The Hard word
results.creator_credit: Scott Roberts, Al Clark and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Taking its cues from the harder edged of the classic crime genre spectrum (in particular Stanley Kubrick’s The Killing), writer/director Scott Robert’s The Hard word manages to work into the mix some off the wall humour and quirky characterization. Guy Pearce, Joel Edgerton and Damien Richardson star as the Twentyman brothers Dale, Mal and Shane, three hardened criminals serving out a prison sentence for armed robbery. Aided by their very crooked lawyer Frank Malone (a gleefully corrupt Robert Taylor), the brothers are given an early bail release, with one very compromising proviso, they have to pull off a dangerous casino heist. To complicate things further Frank is having an affair with Dale’s wife Carol (played with slutty abandon by Rachel Griffiths). Naturally things go from bad to worse as the heist takes a violent turn and the boys discover that they are being tailed by two dodgy cops (Vince Colossimo and Paul Sonkkila) with an unlawful agenda of their own. Cast includes: Rhondda Findleton, Kym Gyngell, Kate Atkinson.

results.title: The Importance of being earnest [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Asquith, Teddy Baird, Two Cities Films, Javelin and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Film adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s brilliant play “The Importance of being earnest” (1895), adapted and directed for the screen by Anthony Asquith, is probably the best-known comedy of manners in the world. Jack Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff are friends, both bachelors operating in English society hoping to find love in a proper match. Each man has spun lies about a fake identity in order to achieve romance with Gwendolyn Fairfax and Cecily Cardew, respectively. When the two couples meet up at Cecily’s place of residence, their lies unfurl and the true selves of both are revealed. Wilde’s last play is a satire on English society and manners, wonderfully sending up the portentousness and pomposity of the upper classes. Two particularly memorable characters are the boorish snob Lady Bracknell and the dithering governess Miss Prism (the latter played with import here by Margaret Rutherford). Asquith never quite transcends the script’s theatrical origins, but does successfully recreate the cadence and spirit of Wilde’s sardonic, barbed wit.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Tim Sanders, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen, by building extensive realistic sets in his native New Zealand, and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

results.title: Ordinary decent criminal
results.creator_credit: Thaddeus O'Sullivan, Jonathan Cavendish, Little Bird and ICON
results.brief_description: Kevin Spacey plays Michael Lynch, a suave and cocky Irish gangster who has something of a reputation with ordinary folk as a local hero. With a loyal gang and always two steps ahead of the law, Michael plans numerous heists, such as a daylight robbery of a precious Caravaggio, along with pulling ordinary bank jobs and robbing his own dole office. Michael’s unusual home life consists of two partners, who are sisters, and numerous children, a delightful arrangement for one and all. Enraged by Michael’s elusiveness and brazen disregard for authority, the police place him and his lot under unyielding surveillance, but the scallywag gives them the slip every time. “Ordinary decent criminal” is a reworking of the true to life Martin Cahill story as told in “The General” (John Boorman, 1998), a far more cynical film about crime. O’Sullivan’s film has a certain incongruity in tone - it is mostly jaunty with a hip soundtrack, but occasionally cuts to violent encounters. Spacey depicts Lynch as a clever, vain and loveable rouge with a wry smile, but a thief and swindler at heart.

results.title: When we were kings [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Taylor Hackford, Leon Gast, David Sonenberg and DAS Films
results.brief_description: The heavyweight title fight between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman in Kinshasa (Zaire) on 30 October 1974 - `The Rumble in the Jungle’ - is enshrined as one of the great sports events of the century. It was also a cultural and political happening. Utilizing original footage of the fight, the film is on one level a lost documentary revealing never-before-seen images of the Fight of the Century between a then relatively unpopular, but fearsome, boxer named George Foreman and his nearly mythical antagonist, the incomparable Muhammad Ali. Filmmakers Gast and Hackford also construct a riveting story of the drama and significance of an event which signified the beginning of a new age of black culture and identity. Complete with performances by B.B. King, James Brown, and Miriam Makeba, marked by the launching of the career of notorious promoter Don King, and overshadowed by the ominous presence of Zaire’s President Mobutu, this is a discourse on what it meant to be black in America in that tumultuous time. Not only does the film deal with issues of segregation and integration and the emergence of black pride and black consciousness, but most critically, it describes the return to Africa of black American visitors. At the centre of the film is Ali, who, both as athlete and entertainer, persona and man, is a compelling figure, deeply committed to issues of racial, religious and political justice. The film also features insights and commentary from Norman Mailer, George Plimpton, and Spike Lee.

results.title: Mousehunt
results.creator_credit: Gore Verbinski, Bruce Cohen, Tony Ludwig, Alan Richie and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: When their elderly father dies, two brothers inherit the family business - the Smuntz string factory - along with a dilapidated house. Ernie Smuntz (Nathan Lane) was a once revered chef but is no more thanks to an unfortunate incident involving the mayor and a cockroach; brother Lars (Lee Evans) is a devoted string factory worker. On viewing the house they discover that it was designed by a revered architect at the turn of the century and is potentially worth millions. The only obstacle to the impending fortune is one wily long time resident, a mouse that’s proving impossible to catch. Christopher Walken has a brief role as a pest exterminator. The film is rated PG due to potentially horrible traps laid by each opponent, including a freakish cat. Cast also includes Vicki Lewis, Eric Christmas and Maury Chaykin.

results.title: Jesus Christ superstar (2000)
results.creator_credit: Gale Edwards and Really Useful Films
results.brief_description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice’s rock opera, “Jesus Christ Superstar” is one of the most successful theatrical musicals of all time. The story of Jesus’ Passion is scored to a vibrant, electronic rock beat and is performed by a cast of dancers and singers. This version, following on from Norman Jewison’ 1973 feature film of the same name, is primarily the filming of a stage production, performed in London, 1996-2000. The accent has shifted and stress is now placed on the perspective of Judas, casting him as a man in conflict with Jesus over the direction the cause has taken. Modernisation of the sets and costumes is reflected in the multicultural cast that are dressed in modern garb - including techno gear and Darth Veda-ish masks. The songs however remain the same and it is through their singing that the full tragedy and power of the Passion is realised. Songs include” “Jesus Christ Superstar”, “What’s the Buzz” and “I Don’t Know How to Love Him.” Cast includes Glenn Carter, Jerome Pradon, Renee Castle, Fred Johanson, Rik Mayall, Frederick B. Owens, Michael Shaeffer.

results.title: Mystery men
results.creator_credit: Kinka Usher, Lloyd Levin, Mike Richardson, Lawrence Gordon, Dark Horse Entertainment, Golar and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the comic book series “The Dark Horse”, by Bob Burden, “Mystery men” is a twisted take on popular superhero films. In a futuristic city, crime has been all but erased by a vain superhero, Captain Amazing, who, with sponsors to placate, is in need of a supervillian to foil. Amazing’s alter ego paroles psychopath Casanova Frankenstein, jailed in an insane asylum for many years. When Amazing goes missing, it is up to the mystery men of the title to free him. The initial posse consists of Mr Furious (speciality is throwing tantrums), The Shoveller, and The Blue Raja, an expert at fork and spoon throwing. These three decide to expand their gang and recruit Spleen man (poisonous farts), The Bowler, Invisible Boy and The Sphinx who can shave metal with his mind. “Mystery men”, which had a reasonable budget and contains some impressive special effects, lost big money at the box office when it was released. Despite this the film successfully satirises the genre and is loaded with subversive humour that makes it an interesting comedy. The cast of great comedic talents includes Ben Stiller, Janeane Garafolo, Eddie Izzard, Hank Azaria and Paul Reubens.

results.title: True lies
results.creator_credit: James Cameron, Stephanie Austin and Lightstorm Entertainment
results.brief_description: Harry Tasker is an undercover spy who masquerades to his family as a dull computer salesman. Compounded by Henry’s many inexplicable absences, his wife Helen, feeling neglected and bored with their marriage, turns to sleazy car salesman Simon for excitement. Harry’s latest assignment is on the trail of several missing nuclear warheads that have been stolen by some maniacal Arab terrorists. James Cameron directs here with typical flair for exciting set pieces and a predilection for crude villain/hero and gender stereotypes. Arnold Schwarzenegger embraces the role as the omnipotent and duplicitous Harry who can tackle any form of violence and danger but whose response to a marriage crisis is to kidnap his wife, subject her to a terrifying interrogation, then send her on a bogus assignment as a prostitute. At the time of release the film was read as a cheeky update of the genre, but it offers quite a limited re-imaging of a James Bond type of hero. The best features are the film’s pace and some exciting chase sequences across rooftops and amidst exploding bridges et al. Imbued with generic trademark humour, “True lies” garnered criticism for its cliched representation of Arabic people and an excruciating scene where Helen strips for, (unknowingly), her husband.

results.title: The Funeral
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Mary Kane and October Films
results.brief_description: Working from an original screenplay from his long time collaborator Nicholas St John, Abel Ferrara’s “The Funeral” sees the maverick director working in a more low key mode. That’s not to say of course that “The Funeral” doesn’t have Ferrara’s usual trademarks; seething violence, spiritual males and cathartic redemption. The film’s melancholic study of a crime family in crisis is set off by the murder of 22 year old Johnny Tempio (Vincent Gallo), shot dead in a movie theatre by a rival gang. His grief stricken brothers (Christopher Walken and Chris Penn) vow bloody revenge, while the women (Annabella Sciorra and Isabella Rossellini) of the family look for a more peaceful resolution. Ferrara is a master of transcending conventional genres as he proved with his bold reinvention of the vampire movie in The Addiction (1995) and his rabid cop drama Bad Lieutenant (1992). Again Ferrara manages to transcend the cliches of the gangster film as the bloody quest for revenge becomes an internal affair, leaving the mafia brothers to contemplate the nature of guilt and the futility of retribution. 1996 Venice Film Festival winner for Best Supporting Actor (Chris Penn) and the OCIC (Organisation Catholique Internationale du Cinema) Award for Abel Ferrara. Cast includes: Benicio del Toro, Gretchen Mol.
